title: Red Team Initial Access Tradecraft
subtitle: Crafting entry points that survive modern defenses
concepts: Rules of engagement and safety controls
learning_objectives: Design initial access campaigns aligned with engagement scope and safety rules
Select payload carriers that bypass secure email and web gateways
Instrument callbacks with resilient communication channels and kill switches
Balance stealth, speed, and learning objectives when establishing dwell time
Document artifacts so defenders can build detections and mitigations
Coordinate with white cell teams to maintain ethical and legal compliance

content_blocks.title: Operate With Intentionality

content.text: Initial access is where trust is earned. Treat each campaign like a scientific experiment: define the hypothesis, record every variable, and build in safeties. The objective is not to "get in" at any cost—it is to learn, document, and teach.

content_blocks.simplified_explanation: Plan carefully so you learn more than you break.
content_blocks.real_world_connection: Respected operators keep immaculate logs and can explain every decision to stakeholders and regulators.
content_blocks.reflection_prompt: What is the key learning outcome you want from your next initial access run?

content_blocks.title: Campaign Blueprint

content.text:
## Build, Deliver, Sustain
- **Build** – Craft persona, pretext, and payload with appropriate safeties and logging.
- **Deliver** – Select channels (phish, web, supply chain) and rehearse them.
- **Sustain** – Establish callbacks, persistence, and containment triggers.

content_blocks.simplified_explanation: Plan for the life-cycle: setup, execution, and post-access control.
content_blocks.real_world_connection: Engagement plans often mirror this slide to brief white cell teams.
content_blocks.reflection_prompt: Which phase tends to absorb the most time in your experience?

content_blocks.title: SAFE Hooks

content.text:
### S.A.F.E.
- **S**cope confirmation and white cell contacts
- **A**rtifact logging (hashes, lure copy, server configs)
- **F**ail-safe kill switches for callbacks
- **E**thical review before launch

content_blocks.simplified_explanation: Run SAFE every time before you push send.
content_blocks.real_world_connection: Accredited teams use checklists like SAFE to pass compliance audits.
content_blocks.reflection_prompt: Which SAFE step have you skipped in the past? What did it cost?

content_blocks.title: Field Example: Healthcare Spearphish

content.text: A healthcare red team crafted spearphish referencing a recent industry breach. The lure achieved a 38% click rate, but pre-deployed canary accounts triggered an alert within minutes. The lesson: blend email, web, and supply chain vectors to diversify learning while respecting detection investments.

content_blocks.simplified_explanation: Even successful lures must account for modern detections.
content_blocks.real_world_connection: Case study sourced from a regulated medical provider exercise.
content_blocks.reflection_prompt: How would you expand this campaign to include an alternate initial access avenue?

content_blocks.title: Craft an Initial Access Plan

content.text:
1. Choose a target persona and write a three-sentence pretext aligned with recent OSINT.
2. Select a payload carrier (macro doc, HTA, link) and justify why it fits the controls you expect.
3. Define success criteria, kill switches, and clean-up steps.
4. Capture the plan in your engagement notebook and tag white cell reviewers.

content_blocks.simplified_explanation: Rehearse the plan in writing so approvals move quickly.
content_blocks.real_world_connection: Operators often draft this exact plan before requesting go-live sign-off.
content_blocks.reflection_prompt: What is the riskiest assumption in your plan, and how will you validate it?

content_blocks.title: Teach Back the Campaign

content.text:
### Reflect & Teach
- Draft a short audio or written debrief explaining your pretext, payload, and safety controls to a teammate.
- Record two insights you gained about balancing stealth and learning.
- Identify one detection recommendation you will hand to defenders.

content_blocks.simplified_explanation: Teaching clarifies the why behind every engagement decision.
content_blocks.real_world_connection: After every campaign, elite teams hold a hotwash identical to this activity.
content_blocks.reflection_prompt: Who will you share your debrief with this week?

post_assessment.question: What is the main reason to diversify initial access techniques during an engagement?
options: To increase the volume of alerts
To adapt to layered defenses and increase learning value
post_assessment.explanation: Multiple techniques reveal strengths and weaknesses across technology, process, and people.

post_assessment.question: Why should callbacks include safeties and kill switches?
options: To maintain control and terminate immediately if scope is breached
post_assessment.explanation: Safeties protect both client and red team by ensuring activity stays within agreed parameters.

post_assessment.question: What should accompany initial access artifacts in the final report?
post_assessment.explanation: Detailed context empowers defenders to prioritise fixes and replicate detection logic.
